As a general explanation of new ideas like string theory and multiverses, etc, it's pretty readable, for the most part. But some of the ideas get so far off the wall as to seem completely impracticable- i.e; intelligent life surviving the end of the universe. Kaku suggests that a Type III Civilization could escape the death of the universe by escaping into another which it somehow creates itself, loading all its biological information onto quantum computers and sending them through the black hole wormhole, or whatever sort of other artificially gravitational "droplet" has been created to accommodate it. But one thing. Once all the biological information gets there, how do the bots know exactly how to reassemble it? What do the newly transported decanted beings eat? What do they live on when they get there, seeing as they'll somehow need to evolve and grow stars and planets, of course, first? What about the billions of years it will take them even to get to that? Or is the assumption that, by this time, machine bots will have preserved in themselves some fantastic mechanism of consciousness with which they can rationalize survival and reproduction? Perhaps I am "too lay" an astrobiology fan to be the proper person to review this, which I get for the most part, but am on some other levels, mystified by. People get paid to write books and think about this stuff so you would be hard pressed to get them to admit any of it seems illogical, since they like to prove by logic and equations that such and such even could be possible... But just those questions were increasingly nagging me through the final chapters. It might take the sum value of that Type III Civilization just to create that new universe for its mechanized biota "ark". Which would be of course fantastically economically ridiculous (even if they ruled this universe) and prohibitively expensive. Perhaps a true "Type III Civilization" would be philosophically evolved enough to realize that, everything blooms grows and dies, and there is a beauty and justice in submission to the inescapable reality that this is fine enough.

For a long time, I have been in a bind when it comes to buying books about science or mathematics. My bind is this: I am well versed enough in these subjects to find beginner books rather tedious and often a lot of review rather than exposing new ideas, but I am by no means enough of an expert to pick up a high-end theory or textbook and follow it very easily. This has made a lot of science and math books rather unattainable--I am either going to be bored with it or find it too hard. But Kaku has usually been able to offer good solace, and he does not disappoint with this one. In _Parallel Worlds_, Kaku explores the realms of string theory, quantum universes, time travel, a whole host of experimental physics. Kaku sometimes kowtows to simplifying his subjects to a false degree, but his best analogies explain the wonderful simplicity of an idea as well as its complexities. The issue of dark matter, for example, or what really blew me away was the idea of invisible energy, attraction created between two parallel metal plates not by charge but by an imbalance of virtual particles between the outsides and insides of the metal. Kaku is fine with presenting highly theoretical ideas that have no present means for testing and confirmation, and he is very objective with most about them when it comes to their plausibility and potential faults. Since he has helped develop string theory, he of course has a lot of hope for it, but his overall objectivity and scholarship is enough to trust throughout. Some parts are worth going slowly through, to follow the train of thought that leads to rather anti-intuitive conclusions, but that is the joy of math and science, after all, and this book is well worth that read.

Sitting in the afterglow of the last page, I have to say, I really, really enjoyed this book. Kaku is a wonderful writer who somehow manages to bring a large amount incredibly complex science (as well as the entire known/speculated history of the universe) and condenses it into quite a charming little read. Admittedly, it took me a few months to finally work through, but this was no fault of the author or the content. No, if anything I was surprised by how easily accessible the writing and the tone were; it was like having a friendly conversation with someone you know is fifty times as brilliant as you are, but it's never awkward. The author dances between science, religion, and philosophy without making any sort of commitments; he presents multiple sides of an argument, before briefly mentioning upon his personal views and then gracefully bowing out. I appreciate that. The last chapter in particular was quite touching, and I came away from it positively inspired.I have to imagine that, due to the mentions of pop culture and "current" science, this book is bound to be seen as dated, even within ten years time. (For example, it mentions that the LHC, Large Hadron Collider, was still being built at the time the book was published. But in 2013 scientists are close to confirming the existence of the Higgs boson particle. So.) Still, I think this is definitely a book worth coming back to, not only for the picture it paints of the past, but for the possible views it gives us for the future.

This book, by one of the most talented physics professors of our time, Michio Kaku, is a collection of the leading physics theories and an exploration of the universe. The book focuses mainly on the revolutionary developments in cosmology within the last several years. The author based it on new evidence from the world’s laboratories, the outermost reaches of space, and new breakthroughs in theoretical physics. It is divided into three sections. First, Kaku describes the study of the universe and the evolution of cosmology in “The Universe”. Then, the second section, named “The Multiverse” , explores the theory that our universe is one that exists among many (Superstring theory and M-theory). This section also discusses the possibility of wormholes, space and time warps, and higher dimensions. The third and final section, titled “Escape into Hyperspace”, concentrates on the big freeze, the end of the universe, and the idea that humanity may be able to enter another universe or go back in time when the universe was warmer. I would recommend this book to readers interested in physics and cosmology. Even if these subjects are not of interest, this is an enjoyable book which provides captivating theories and allows fascinating thoughts to develop.

Summary in a nutshell (or rather in a string): Kaku has the gift to put into words some of the most sophisticated theories of physics today. He is the one who came up with the equation that summarizes the field theory of strings. The heart of the electron is a vibrating string, tinier than a proton. If we were to pluck the string, its vibrations would change it into any one of the known subatomic particles. Did you know that the 5th dimension is light? If Einstein had never discovered relativity, his theory might have been discovered as a by-product of string theory, because the lowest vibration is a quantum of gravity. All 11 parallel dimensions are probably encoded in these strings, and might be revealed sometime in our technological future. This book was published in 2005 but most of it still stands today. Perhaps some minor updates for the microwave data from the WMAP satellite (after more recent calculations, 26.8% rather than 23% of the universe is made up of dark matter) and there’s probably more updated information on the LISA antenna and the Large Hadron Collider which are mentioned in the book but were not yet built at the time of publication. Excellent ‘theory of everything’ for everyone!

There's really no reason for me to be surprised: I guess I had just grown so used to seeing him on TV that I subconsciously gave him less credit than he obviously deserves. Recommended.

Kaku (Hyperspace) teaches theoretical physics at City University of New York. Sound daunting? It is-considering he deals with recent satellite data suggesting that mysterious dark energy makes up nearly three-quarters of the universe. Parallel Worlds, which meshes Kaku's interests in physics and futurology, asks hair-raising questions: Do higher dimensions exist? Can black holes bend time? And if our universe is dying, will we be able to jump ship to another? Kaku runs through the recent history of cosmology, from Newton to Einstein, and introduces his own theories. He writes clearly, and a good glossary helps. But with many digressions and complex concepts, most readers will need some help. A few critics recommended starting with Brian Greene's Fabric of the Cosmos (**** May/June 2004), a snappier, though still difficult, book. Or, just go to superstringtheory.com. That'll clear it right up.This is an excerpt from a review published in Bookmarks magazine.

Michio Kaku's Parallel Worlds is a welcome entry in the genre of popular physics. Parallel Worlds tracks recent developments in the realm of cosmology and presents in a wholly engaging and accessible manner.The book is divided into three broad sections: the first summarizing the evolution and development of cosmology, the second presenting emerging theories - including superstring theory and M-theory - and the third being something of an extended thought experiment that begins with a narrative of the ultimate demise of the universe and then goes on to posit how a truly advanced civilation might actually escape such an end. While this last section is, of course, purely speculative, it does provide the reader with a useful insights into the universe as it is currently modeled by the latest cosmological theories.Parallel Worlds provides a fascinating glimpse into life, the universe, and everything. Most fans of popular science should find this to be a necessary addition to their libraries.

Engaging and well put together, guiding even the least mathematically minded through the development of quantum physics and cosmology. He blends technical detail with religious debate as he explains how theories have developed, adapted and been debunked. It covers everything from the very small: how sub atomic particles may not be particles at all but strings of energy; to the very large: the Big Bang, the rate of expansion of the universe and whether our universe is only a small outcrop on the edge of a larger one. It does get quite technical in the middle when it gets into explaining how certain theories work in 5, 10, 15 and 22 dimensions; and how those dimensions may be smaller than a subatomic particle. However, the last section of the book becomes as he applies these theories to the very practical issues of how to travel through time, explore new universes and build teleport machines. A great balance which leaves you plenty to ponder as you stare at the stars.

The idea of parallel universes began with Everett Young, a graduate student whose thesis in quantum theory argued that the collapse of the Schrodinger probability wave upon measurement was not really a collaps: measuring a quantum state didn't just cause all states other than the one found to disappear. What happens on measurement, Young argued, was that the universe splits. Tou, the observer, are in one universe where the outcome you see exists, and there are other YOUs that see the other outcomes.This wss very mysterious. Where are all these other universes? How could "reality" split just because a die came up 6? It was considered quackery. But modern physics has increasingly accepted the idea, and Michio Kaku--a real physicist--tells us how and why.Brian Greene's take on the parallel universe notion is, for me, a much better book. I enjoyed Kaku's take, but it seemed like old soup unwarmed.

Michio Kaku is my favourite personality to watch on science documentaries, and he certainly isn't a letdown in his written works as well. There is much straight to the point facts here, so much that it isn't easy or productive to read more than a chapter at one go. Because the book is 'simplified', most of the theories are not fundamentally explained or proven(they aren't in real life anyway), and you just have to accept what's thrown at you. This was exactly the kind of book I was looking for - an introductory book to parallel universes - before I ventured deeper into the concepts.HOWEVER, I still do not think this book is an easy read by any means. Without much passion and love for the subject I feel that many will put the book down after several pages. If you just want to know the very very very basics of parallel worlds so you can understand recent sci-fi movies better, just Google short articles on the subject instead.

I was really hoping this would explain to me WTF dark matter and energy are since I've heard them frequently mentioned the last few years - it doesn't really. But mostly because nobody really knows still.Even though it failed me there, it was a great book to review a lot of what I remember being covered in Brian Greene's "The Fabric of the Cosmos". I definitely spaced out during some sections either because it was covering stuff that I've read about dozens of times already (history of science through Einstein), or because it was covering stuff I have almost no real/intuitive understanding of (string theory), or because I listened to it as an audiobook during my marathon training runs and was tired or trying to avoid being hit by cars. So to truly appreciate it I'd probably have to read it while sitting still and quiet, but it certainly helped the running time pass and was educational.

A beautifully written summary of cosmology up to the beginning of the current millennium and an assessment of the possibilities intelligent life may have for surviving the inevitable death of our own universe. Although published in 2005 and therefore slightly out of date in a few unimportant ways (eg the Large Hadron Collider at CERN was still being built, and he talks excitedly about the possibility of finding the Higgs Boson which was (tentatively) discovered in 2013; he refers to English being the second most widely spoken language on Earth which is no longer true) the substance of the book is relevant and will continue to be so probably for a million years or so. Some of the facts and concepts in the book are truly breathtaking, and despite being largely about theoretical physics, it can't help but stimulate the reader's philosophical gland in considering our place in the universe and in revaluing one's life in the context of just how unlikely an accident that life really is.

I would be lying if I said this was an easy read. Introducing concepts such as dark matter, black holes and event horizons among many others, Kaku does a great job of breaking these down into easy terms to understand sans technical jargon. I struggled mostly with M theory and string theory though and the concept of parallel universes. It was also a good introduction for me to physicists such as Einstein, Heisenberg, Schrodinger, etc. as well as their various theories. What I found especially refreshing was the introduction of the Goldilocks theory (or anthropic principle) which suggested that there may be a God or higher power since the position of Earth from the sun, moon and other planets is just right for life to flourish and exist. This book is my first Michio Kaku book and it's great. Definitely worth a read if you're interested in learning more about the cosmos, quantum mechanics etc.

Magnificent book if you like physics and cosmology; quite updated information.I learned many things, including:The latest discoveries of string theory and M theory .... And I do not like at all these theories, they seem to me mathematical games made without any basis or proof in real life, so not scientific (as well have millions of possible solutions). They remind me the demonstrations of St. Thomas Aquinas, but with mathematics.Now, regarding the Schrödinger cat I do not like or agree with this paradox. The cat is dead or alive, it is conscious to that, not mattering if a human would not; therefore function collapses anyway.But the most interesting part of the book is the future of the universe, which await only two destinations: death by cooling (because it is constantly growing and cooling) or death by a Big Crunch .... I think the first is the most probable.Speculations of how an intelligent civilization could survive the end of the universe are very enriching.

Oh wow. What an excellent and disturbing read.First of all, when reviewing, each person has a purpose. I'm not reviewing this book as a book for someone who has a deep knowledge of physics and wants more specialized knowledge. Nor am I reviewing this as a book for the mainstream for someone who has no idea of the basic physics principles. I'm reviewing this book as for someone that has a basic knowledge of physics, engineering, whatever academic experience is it, but that will give you an underlying understanding of the basic principles, and that wants some specialized knowledge summed up in quick and clear fashion.For that purpose, this is an excellent book. To take your basic understanding of physics and tell you what the main theories are, the pros and cons of each, and to give a perspective of how we might evolve and what we might find next. It's an excellent snapshot.Will re-read many times in the future.

I liked the book because a lot of the way it describes Michio Kaku's theoretical process through verbal visualization as well as the thought process he used to kind of get an understand of the cosmos in his own way. Another reason I liked the book was that it is just an intricate spider web type perspective on religious beliefs as well as his description of his own religious standpoint which I thought was cool considering that a lot of astrophysicists don't believe in a “Higher power” but instead believe that the cosmos is what always will be, I also liked how he gave credit to scientists that kind of “paved the way” with their work so to speak by allowing him to use their theories and scientific calculations to further his own work on a similar concept on that of the cosmos, and when I say credit them I am of course talking about the beginning of the book where he gets the more simple concepts out of the way.

A very pedestrian text. It's unexpected how dull Kaku makes this whole subject. He's very bad at explaining physical phenomena and complex scientific ideas. He just does not have any lucidity whatsoever. He states complex scientific solutions for fact, and never tries to make them make sense or elucidate on the underlying processes. Sometimes he tries to use analogies, but his effort in this regard ultimately comes off as an unskilled imitation of Brian Greene and the latter's facile analogies. Kaku doesn't know how to do it. His attempt becomes mechanical and artificial and is repugnant to read. He fully fails in his endeavor of writing science. Moreover, on occasion, he veers well into the spiritual and religious interpretations of science, which is nearly criminal for the genre he presents himself in.It's a dumb, low-quality book. The explanations are juvenile and don't seem to have been thought through. What a disappointing author.

As always Michio provides a thought provoking & interesting read. He has a great talent of explaining complicated physics in simpler terms giving just the right amount of depth without bogging you down in the mathematics behind the theories. I really enjoy his method of working through the historical theories & how they evolved into what we know & theorise today.As the name suggests this book walks us through the theories that lead to multiple universes budding & branching off from each other & also the multiverse theory of parallel words spawned by quantum physics. He then moves on to question how intelligent life may be able to survive in the far future as our universe is coming to an end. The last chapter that delves into theology felt a little brief & out of place but I guess that's a whole new debate.Overall it's a great read for anyone with an interest in the wider scope of universes outside of our own.

Skip Part III and you’ve got a great read here. Part I and II of this book provide an outstanding overview of quantum mechanics, string theory and M theory, and the state of things in particle physics right up to the LHC. Kaku’s writing style is engaging and fun to read and he cites all the heavy hitters and some of the lesser-known players in the physics community. This is a good starting point to discover other publications on the topic of time, string theory, many worlds theory, and quantum mechanics. While he references concepts from science fiction novels throughout the book, it doesn’t become problematic until Part III, which is an exercise in pure speculation. I wish the editor would have suggested that Part III be relocated to some other space and time so it wouldn’t mar this otherwise highly-enjoyable book.

Kaku tells the story of the universe which includes everything and the kitchen sink. He approaches advanced topics in physics from the perspectives of art, music, and literature. I was shocked to learn that Edgar Allen Poe was an amateur physicist who first proposed some legitimate theories. Overall, it's very interesting, though Parallel Worlds often seems to suffer from it's own form of paradox. It tries sometimes to be too approachable: repeating simple concepts most seventh graders can easily grasp. Other times Kaku deliberately writes with complex technical detail, often with hilarious results.At one point Kaku describes a telescope with an electronic image sensor hilighted by "4,000,000 picture elements." To which I thought, "a 4 Megapixel camera… so what?"It's still a good read, and provides a fresh look at pop physics.

This is my second book by Michio Kaku. Like any other book of the similar kind, this book too starts off with the entire history or various physics theories and then reviewing various points which these theories postulate. As usual there is a mix of Christian/Chinese religious thoughts. Unfortunately the author has not mentioned the Indian religious philosophies about the creation of the universe which are much more advanced in terms of multiple universes and to and fro travel between these universes.Nevertheless, in view of the modern research in quantum and cosmological worlds, this book presents an excellent read. This book mentions LHC being built at Switzerland, which now is live and couple of days back there was a news item about LHC found the Higgs Bosons, the God Particle. I would wait and see what further developments take place now since the God particle has been found.

Kaku is probably my favorite "hard" science writer, and he, Dennett and Dawkins (on science not theology) are my favorites who are living. Kaku presents his ideas such as to make them fun, easy reading. He deals with a lot of "what if" scenarios, and more than most modern physicists he follows his flights of fancy. I imagine that, in most cases, unless you know how to build a particle accelerator in your basement, you're not going to get excited by a tome on cosmological constants and the mathematical flatness of the universe. Kaku, however, is just as happy talking about science fiction as he is talking the mathematics of a black hole, and his enthusiasm is contagious. Parallel Worlds is no let-down, and any looking for a fascinating book about modern science that brim with imaginative possibilities should check Kaku's work out.

My friends are free to keep the "nerd" comments coming, but I genuinely enjoy Kaku's writing style, and Parallel Worlds is one of a number of his books that I've read. His use of analogies makes the concepts fairly easy to understand and absorb, although sacrificing their mathematical portions. However, as interesting as the book was, I found that it seemed like a slightly more confusing version of Kaku's earlier work, Hyperspace. Parallel Worlds tackled many of the same ideas, but was structured in a way that seemed choppier and a little more confusing to follow. Although I think Hyperspace might be a longer read, I'd recommend reading that one first, at the very least. Parallel Worlds does hit on some unique concepts that are really interesting, but the overall organization of the book wasn't as easy to get through.

In this thrilling journey into the mysteries of our cosmos, bestselling author Michio Kaku takes us on a dizzying ride to explore black holes and time machines, multidimensional space and, most tantalizing of all, the possibility that parallel universes may lie alongside our own. Kaku skillfully guides us through the latest innovations in string theory and its most recent iteration, M-theory, which posits that our universe may be just one in an endless multiverse, a singular bubble floating in a sea of infinite bubble universes. If M-theory is proven correct, we may perhaps finally find an answer to the question, "What happened before the big bang?" This is an exciting and unforgettable introduction to the cutting-edge theories of physics and cosmology from one of the preeminent voices in the field.

Parallel Worlds cured me pretty quickly of that burning interest I had in getting up to speed on the multiverse, string theory, and what lies beyond the event horizon that I felt so keenly after I watched Interstellar. The early chapters on relativity, black holes, and quantum theory were pretty engaging, but I started losing my moorings in string theory and by the time Kaku hit his stride theorizing about how humankind might escape our universe in a couple hundred million years, I just wasn't feeling it. Theoretical physics just seems so cabalistic after a certain point. Plus, I couldn't keep my quasars straight. I guess I'll just wonder at the recent images from Pluto and whatever was going on at the end of Kubrick's 2001 and let greater minds hash out the details of space's next frontiers and the future of the universe.

This book starts out, like many popular books on science, talking about very basic science like Newton. It then goes on to talk about Einstein, which is more complicated but still if you took some physics in collage you learned about relativity. I totally get why Kaku does this, he has to assume that the basic reader knows nothing. Thing if you like to read popular science book like I do, you get pretty tiered reading about Newton and Einstein in every book.That being said when the book starts to explore interesting concepts it really gets going and I really enjoyed it. Kaku writes about some really interesting ideas that I would love to explore more. I really can recommend it especially the second half.Although in the version I read said that the antagonist in the matrix were aliens which everyone should know isn't correct!

Parallel Worlds: A Journey Through Creation, Higher Dimensions, and the Future of the Cosmos. By Michio KakuThis book clearly explains theories allusive to many of us who are not physics scientists. Kaku presents the theories chronologically: blackholes, time, multidimential space, and the most intriguing, the possibility that worlds may be occurring right next to our own.“The problem lies not in relativity but in assuming that our common sense represents reality.”Philosophical and scientific. Did God play dice with the universe, as Einstein asked, or are there answers yet to come. “What happened before the beginning? Can time be reversed? Can dimensional gateways take us across the universe?” Kaku takes the reader on a thrilling ride...in just as entertaining a way as many science fiction writers.

This is the second book I have read written by Michio Kaku and he does a very good job of taking complex concepts and explaining them in a layman's language. He points out that a lot of what he discusses in this book goes against common sense, but also reminds us that our common sense is developed in our middle earth world. In the land of the very small and the very big you quickly realize you are not in Kansas anymore. Particles that can be in two different places at once, multiple dimensions and universes, and the potential for time travel are all concepts that are discussed in the book. I found only a few spots where Michio wades a little too deep in the knowledge pool and I needed to skim ahead to get back to solid ground. He definitely makes the future look amazing as scientist unlock even more mysteries about this universe we live in.

This was the second book I read from Kaku. The first was Physics of the Impossible, which I also really enjoyed. This book does a great job of explaining quantum theories and some string theories without being too mathematical. I'm not super great with math, so that helps a lot. He gives much more than just what these theories are, but also what the implications are and what it means for our future. He is very much someone who looks into the future of what sorts of technologies we can create and what it could look like. The big question is- can we get there? I feel we are still among a strong anti-intellectualism and religious fundamentalism that makes progress quite slow at times. But there are still dedicated people to the sciences that make these breakthroughs that are talked about in this book. A lot of it takes a lot of thought to comprehend, but it is fascinating.

I started reading about string theory around a year ago; this was a big deal for someone avowedly not a "science person" I think the best way to get into this frequently mind-bending subject is the shotgun approach. I'd start with the PBS doc THE ELEGANT UNIVERSE, then maybe Brian Greene's FABRIC OF THE COSMOS, and then this book. There's a lot of overlap which is the point since you're guaranteed to not understand everything the first time through (or even the 3rd, 4th, 5th...) Another surprisingly good general science book to add to the above is Bill Bryson's HISTORY OF EVERYTHING for which there's a nice unabridged audiobook available. I may start with Lisa Randall's book WARPED PASSAGES after a little bit of a breather. Any other suggestions on general science tomes?

This was a fascinating book to start me on my journey learning about string theory and cosmology. I got quite a lot of ideas for not only current writing projects but future ones. Kaku-san does such a good job of bringing together cosmology, quantum physics, theology, morality and ethics, environmental issues, and more. Towards the end it got a bit overwhelming, but I worked through and took diligent notes. I don't know that I agree with Kaku-san's belief that we are living in the most desirable time for humanity, but I do agree that we are on the cusp of achieving something really big - or loosing it all. If you're interested in getting a "bigger picture" look at where we are (as of 2005), I highly recommend this read. You won't be disappointed.

Having read this when it first came out back in 2006, Kaku was my first introduction to the "parallel worlds" hypothesis. It blew my mind. If you haven't yet heard, we live in a multiverse of infinite universes that exist all around us in hidden dimensions, and are constantly being created and destroyed by mini big bangs. The most entertaining is Kaku's chapter on futurism, where he makes predictions thousands of millennia into the future. He follows the model of categorizing civilizations based on energy use, from Type 0 civilizations that rely on dead plants for energy, to solar civs that harness atomic energy from their sun, to galactic civs that travel by wormholes and are able to capture the energy of entire galaxies. This is wild stuff.

Wow. Where do I start? First of all, I recommend this book to anyone that has an interest in the origin of our universe, quantum mechanics and string theory but yet need it all explained to you without it insulting your intelligence. This book takes you on a journey through the minds of the best scientists of our time and helps you to understand how the view of the universe came to be. Not only is our universe amazing on a grand scale, but there's a lot more to it than what we can see. The smaller things are in scale, the more bizarre things seem to be. However, we are the oddballs of the universe, as you'll come to learn. Expect to be amazed and have your mind blown.

Great book!!! This book is where I learned how you can be your mother, father, and yourself. (Baby girl is mysteriously delivered to an orphanage, when she turns seventeen she meets a dashing young man who then gets her pregnant. She has the baby, then right after she has it, the baby and the man disappear. Due to complications from the birth, she has to get a sex change operation. So now she's a man. Years later he builds a time machine, goes back in time and meets his teenage girl self. He gets her pregnant, then when the baby is born he kidnaps the baby, goes back even further in time, and delivers the baby to the orphanage) *applause*

Mind-boggling. Not only a great explanation of modern cosmology, particle physics, quantum theory, string theory, and beyond, but also a great history of all the people (who now have buildings and theories and various phenomena named after them) and breakthroughs that made it all possible.Kaku explains it all in probably the most understandable way possible, and avoids the use of equations completely. Even so, this stuff is very hard to understand, even from such a great interpreter. I'd be happy if I understood even 10% of it. This is the first book I've ever read where I wished it had chapter reviews and quizzes. I'll definitely read it again someday.

This was a very exciting and wonderfully poignant work describing parallel worlds, higher dimensions, and the multiverse as a whole, as predicted by M-Theory. Very thorough and informative for a reader who has no scientific background. Some of the concepts are a little hard to understand, but they are cleverly put together in a way that after a few minutes of reflection, one can grasp the meaning. I enjoyed this book, though Carl Sagan was by far the greatest science popularizer. If you want to know a thorough update on how science has changed in the last century, as well as get current updates in the field, check this book out!

Whew! That was a lot to absorb. Mr. Kaku did an excellent job of taking a very complex esoteric subject and putting it in to words a layman could understand. Unfortunately, it was still a little too much for this layman. The first half of the book was the best. The history of Newton and the laws of gravity and motion, then on the Einstein and relativity, and then to many other theories. One could follow a progression of thought and research. The last half dealt with multi-dimensional worlds (11 dimensions is the current theory) and multi-universes. That is where I really bogged down. I will read at least one more of his books; but, not for a while.

This book is a science based review of alternate universes and their relevance to us. Michio Kaku moves into astrophysics and cosmology within this book; broadening approaches enormously. With simple explanations of strings, m-theory, and black holes there is also focus on the importance of electromagnetism. This book makes reference to the universe that we are not alone; and the possible travel connection to parallel universes. Michio Kaku makes an appealing presentation in science that connects to the everyday world. There is a list of contacts in the physicist community for other interesting reading.

Very much your standard Michio Kaku book. Enjoyable, clear, and something you'll probably be all the smarter for reading. If you've spent time reading books like "The Elegant Universe", "The Fabric of the Cosmos", or "4% Universe", a LOT of this will serve as a very high-level review. However, even then, Kaku's review of gravity comes with a few interesting and vivid examples, and for that alone it may be worth reading for the cosmologically curious. The final chapters are great fun if you like thinking about possible scenario about the future history of the universe (SCIFI FOLKS, TAKE NOTE!), and those alone make the book worth it.

Another excellent and highly readable book from physicist Michio Kaku. Of particular interest: Kaku relating the various levels of civilization, where we fall on that rising scale and what we would need to accomplish (and overcome) to reach the next level. And more significantly: What various civilizations may be able to do and profit from through time, to better human life and escape the inevitable destruction of the Earth. Kaku concludes his book by writing thoughtfully and gracefully about the intersection of religion and science, arriving at views about the meaning of life which are both intellectually satifying and spiritually uplifting.

Parallel Worlds.....Once again Michio Kaku explains the reality of the possibilities of parallel universes and alternate dimensions. He impresses the importance of finding a "Theory of Everything" and how both quantum mechanics and super string theory/m-theory are the key to our understanding the Universe, our part in it and how we advance to the next level of civilisation. This was a great book and gives many references to other books/authors that relate to the subject which I have already obtained for future reading. Dr Kaku's enthusiasm for his work always makes for an enjoyable experience when reading his works.

An excellent book.Michio Kaku eloquently takes the reader inside the creation of the universe like we've never heard before: the bubbling of universe, the creation of universes (multi-verse), and the paradoxes that come with its early theories. He explained not only the realms outside our 4-dimensional world, but also extensively discuss how we might get to "the other side".The kind of book that can make you pause and ponder about your very own existence. The one that can make you question your own purpose in this unfathomably vast universe. Kaku successfully took the reader on an inspiring journey, trying to do what Einstein once called "reading the mind of God".

I really did appreciate Dr. Kaku's extensive expertise and knowledge, but in the same regard-I do feel like Kaku surely does seem to pander to both creating this current sort of 'futurist alarmist' culture and he also panders to this overtly middle of the road religious types of reader. Not cool Kaku, why not just let science be science rather than adding on some wild conjecture all for the sake of 'shock value' and or that of being 'so outlandish' that you stand out. It's not necessary as you are a real scientist, so here's to you going back to your roots and not trying to appeal to everyone.

The most recent stuff from the world of theoretical physics, all broken down so that mere mortals like you and I can understand them. Covers new discoveries that have thrown science as we know it on its ear. The mind-numbing concept of mutiverses described as soap bubbles so that it actually makes sense to even the most non-scientific of readers. When a book can make theoretical physics this approachable to us laymen, it has really done an outstanding job. Michio Kaku is a rock star in this world of science.

This is a brain-stretching book! I admit that I didn't understand a lot of it, but the parts I do "get" are fun to think about. He actually explains Einstein's theory of relativity as simply as I have ever heard it done. Also, quarks, quantum theory, oiler/beta function, atom smashers, string theory, and M theory.(I listened to this book on my ipod from Audible) He states that the language of nature is mathematics, and asks the question - "Is the universe a hologram?" If you are facinated with how the cosmos works and the history of physics you will enjoy this book.

Parallel Worlds forms a nice little Venn diagram with Charles Seife’s Decoding the Universe and The Elegant Universe, Brian Greene. It’s a great resource to fill in some of the gaps, but as a whole, was a little too focused on far distant hypothetical futuristic visions to live up to the meaty science of the other two books.I like how, in chapter seven, Kaku says we are all born scientists as children, only most of us neglect to continue our love of it as adults. And mathematics is usually the brick wall. (Yep.)

Professor Kaku explains the latest physical theories of the cosmos in remarkably accessible and lively prose. Summarizing the history of cosmology, he highlights the seemingly contradictory ways in which large things, like baseballs, planets and galaxies act to the way very small things like electrons and quarks behave. He then goes on to black holes, time travel and the theoretical possibility that, in the far future, intelligent beings might escape a cold dying universe into another one, perhaps one of their own creation.

this book is not an easy read by any means, especially for someone that has no knowledge of quantum mechanics and particle physics. I love the way Kaku portrays all of the concepts presented in the book with applications to science fiction novels or potential future technology. it took me a while to read this because I would often stop and think about the theories presented. if you're curious about where we came from and where we are going, definitely read this book! it doesn't have all the answers, but it's full of intriguing scientific theory bordering on philosophy.

The premise of the book is that we exist in 11 dimensions which no matter how crazy sounding is empirically, mathematically and most-likely possible thanks to String Theory, a theory of everything (also called M-Theory). String theory explains physics from the smallest sub-atomic particles to the vastness of the known universe and everything in-between that's why they refer to it as a theory of everything. Kaku joins the dots in scientific discoveries and even uses science fiction to help explain the theory which he himself was a part of discovering.

In 'Parallel Worlds', Michio Kaku's writing style is all about keeping the reader riveted by the astounding facts and research information in the astronomical world. Terrific! He explains almost all the mind-boggling concepts that are known to the astrophysicist fraternity, in a very enthusiastic and lucid manner. If you happen to be someone who likes the subject of cosmology this book will take your interest a notch above! And if you happen to be someone who does not know much on this field, this book will ignite an eternal quest for knowledge about our universe, rather 'Multiverse' !

Parallel Worlds is very engaging and does delve into some interesting concepts especially in regard to black holes, wormholes, and of course parallel worlds. Definitely re-hashes (and sometimes lifts intact) chapters in other books by Kaku. This is understandable but somewhat tiresome if you are familiar with the other works. He can be quite illustrative and willing to imagine beyond what can be easily projected. The speculative aspects of the Future of the Cosmos sets this apart from others writing in the field.

Parallel Worlds is an outstanding book that introduces the reader to the colorful world of physics. The subject discusses present day investigations and many previous discoveries that prove to be quite enlightening. Kaku's simplicity of writing is easily understood and invaluable when discussing such serious fields of science. The stories of important forerunners such as Einstein and Schrodinger are so involving as the reader follows their every move to discover the secret and the possibilities that reside in our amazing universe.

Decent book on multiverse theory, though it takes a really long time for Kaku to get from the theoretical astrophysics to that core topic.Though heavy reading at times, the repetitious nature of Kaku's writing was his real fault. If someone was to run a language concordancer on the book, I wouldn't be surprised if the same group of words crop up over and over again...Nevertheless, there was plenty of content that I bookmarked for further reading - a decent guide to the multiverse theory.

Only surpassed by Brian Cox, I think Michio Kaku writes about advanced physics in a wonderful creative way, slowly narratively explaining the most advanced theories and discoveries and the history on how they where found. I probably will re-read the book in a year or so to really hammer in some of the points. The only thing that annoyed me was the phrasing of the "greatest discovery/theory of all times", which should say "... In our time" as that definitely will change over time. Otherwise, a good read!

I'm exhausted. Don't get me wrong, I really enjoyed the book but it really took me close to 6 months to finish. Chapters on future civilizations and multi-verses were fascinating. I hit the wall on String Theory. I don't know if I can tell you much about it even though the concept was touched on several times. There's so much to think about and understand at times in certain chapters that I just couldn't get up to getting to read about it for weeks. But there's so much fascinating science all throughout the book that when I was able to follow along, I really enjoyed it.

One of the best concise book to read about scientific explorations and advancements and starter for Understanding the Quantum Universe.This beautiful quote by Martin Gardner mentioned in book “Why does the apple fall? Because of the law of gravitation. Why the law of gravitation? Because of certain equations that are part of the theory of relativity. Should physicists succeed some day in writing one ultimate equation from which all physical laws can be derived, one could still ask, ‘Why that equation?’ ”explains and displays how good this book is. :-)

As a first timer in the field of astronomy, I greatly enjoyed this book. The book is not a short one and the material is pretty much unfamiliar to me, but the book still managed to be a page turner. Michio Kaku is a great writer. He first captured my attention to the field of astronomy in several Youtube videos that I watched of him and now my attention to this field has been further enhanced because of this book.On the cons side, I felt like sometimes he stumbles in the explanation in some of the concepts which resulted in me getting lost a lot. Hence the four star rating.

Really not a bad book. Michio Kaku takes this incredibly complex idea and boils it down to a consumable book. With that being said, this book isn't for the faint of heart. While some concepts are easier to grasp than others, there is a large chunk of this book in which I went on "screensaver mode". Certainly no fault of the author, but I don't have near the background to grasp many of these concepts at a high level.With that being said, I found it very fascinating. This would have made for a decent sci-fi book if it weren't true.

Is there anything more absurdly fantastic than the universe that we live in ? I have read a number of books describing the quantum field for the laymen and this was far and away the easiest and best to understand . I remember seeing the author talk on Good Morning America tv show in New York where I used to work as stagehand and he was always a delightful and easy guest discussing whatever scientific topic he was explaining . This was my first Kaku book , I loved it and I will plow right in to another one of his works directly

Interesting. A bit if a rehash of his older books, but what the hey... the Universe is still the Universe. Can't expect our knowledge of it to change drastically in between publications for any one author on the subject.His speculative thoughts about the near and very far futures of mankind were interesting and thought-provoking while at the same time being just a wee bit out there, but speculation such as this is expected to be a bit broad and fantastical.All in all, not a bad read for those interested in Physics and Cosmology.

A bit too much repetition from the Hyperspace. Additionally it was published 10 years ago, and reader have to bare in mind, that lately a decade in physics makes a big difference in terms of theories and experiments. For example, since the publication of that book, both the gravity waves, and the Higgs Bozon were found. Also, for me it was a bit too much of speculation upon some concepts, but definitely worth reading for anyone who is interested in modern physics. A bit less that 4 stars, but much more than 3.

An interesting and thorough description of our current understanding of the universe, and potential multiverse, complete with speculation of the future of our species and our origins. It seems as though many of Kaku's assumptions are based on the premise that M theory is correct and we are just waiting on evidence. That may be the case but we dont know yet. I very much enjoyed this book about physics and cosmology written by a physicist and futurist. I have informally studied cosmology since I was a teenager and I was very pleased to encounter new ideas to me in this work.

I often say that Nature, in itself, has all the philosophy. Reading a popular science book is generally an emotionally overwhelming experience for me. The sheer simplicity of the universal oneness of all beings and things - never fails to push me into an introspective mode where all my emotions come together and kill whatever hubris I have. That feeling of nothingness and meaninglessness is somehow the most beautiful purgatory feeling in the whole world. Don't read the book to look for any answers from the outside world. Read - just to understand - that all the answers lie within us.

I learned that our universe is doomed to a 'big freeze' trillions of years from now unless we can find a way to escape to/create a warmer parallel universe, or instead think really really slowly over the course of millions of years in near absolute zero temperatures.Seriously though, a good read if you're interested in what we know about the universe today (2007), string theory, multiverse theories.

This is a very reader-friendly look at an extremely complex scientific topic - M Theory. I found the writing to be excellent and only got lost a few times! Although it is on the edge of acceptable science, the author makes a fascinating subject so accessible that it is worth reading just for this reason. I hope that some of Michio Kaku's more aggressive theories turn out to be true. It would make for a fantastic future.

Michio Kaku, like Carl Sagan, is a rare mind. He combines deep, direct knowledge and experience in theoretical physics and cosmology and yet can communicate what it all means to the more common brain (like mine.) This book is no exception.String theory, M-theory and the notion of an infinite number of possible universes are real bogglers and difficult to grasp from a three-dimensional point of view. Parallel Worlds makes it all quite accessible.

Temporarily setting this aside with definite plans to return to it. I waited too long to start it, and it was due back to the library ... I could have rechecked it, but decided I wanted some lighter fare before returning to finish this excellent piece of seriously mind-stretching science writing.Set aside 1/9/2009, on page 261 ... get it back soon! :)OST NON-FICTION ADULT STK 523.1 KAK TWIS book club selection for November 2008

What I love about Kaku's writing is how it's just the right mix of hardcore science and science fiction. He discusses the topics that you think up while reading or watching sci-fi and presents them clearly and with real scientific background. He makes the science interesting to the reFer, provides just the right amount of philosophy & history, and mentions lots of interesting little bits of trivia along the way.It's an excellent read and well worth the journey.

This book is a great introduction to physics, the universe, mysteries of life in general. Good overview of the way in which discoveries grew upon each other to form current beliefs. Don't need to be good at math to get a general understanding and be fascinated - though I wish I could grasp it all to the depths that the author has reached. A Must Read. Hoping to get my mathandphysics-smart family members to read it and then discuss it with me.

Read this book after his other best-seller - Physics of the Impossible. Should have been around :)In terms of writing is not as accessible as the Physics but nevertheless it dwells with some very interesting issues. Particularly how civilization will cope with the end of the Universe and try to escape it to another Universe. It also provides some background explanation on key concepts, which is very useful.

This book is a few years old, so some of the information is either dated or borderline defunct. That being said, I still adore Kaku's remarkable ability to bridge the gap between science and science fiction...with authority. I also like the way he "teaches". He reviews earlier concepts and finds ways to re-illustrate them and make them stick. If you struggle with symmetry & supersymmetry, Kaku is your guy.

"Don't be afraid"Okay, so maybe, just maybe I understood 10% of this book? No big deal. There was always just enough that I could understand to keep me reading; I mean listening. The voice of the narrator is beautiful. There is enough repetition to actually help one to have some understanding of some rather deep stuff. I'll listen to it again and I think I will understand more. I know I will enjoy it again.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book; it is well written and well explained.It covers all aspects of cosmology and their implications regarding time travel, parallel worlds, string theory and black holes. Mr.Kaku presents the idea of multiverses that co-exist in a string, subject to ongoing Big Bangs. It is a wonderful book and I recommend to anyone with or without physics knowledge.

It was a bit too popular and less science for me... I had the audio version and I was almost through when my phone got stolen and I couldn't recover my most recent place... So I decided to give up on it. The issue fascinates me, but I just couldn't get into the book as it didn't go deep enough in my opinion. Obviously Michio Kaku is well versed in that subject but in order to make it more palatable for the crowds, the book became over simplified.

This book offers an update on cosmology as well as a general background history for lay people.It covers all the latest theories and then postulates on the future of our universe and how we could escape when it ends. The book was understandable to my relatively small unscientific brain and contained many astounding facts and ideas that kept it rolling along at a good pace. Also on the plus side is the notes and glossary section along with a fantastic cover.

Exploring the theories to unite micro and macro science through historical finding in our universe. Can we unite Relative theory and Quantum theory in one? Is there any religion already perceived such concept and apply its belief and practice in daily life? Do you think you go heaven after this life and just enjoy, or born again in next life like human again somewhere in one of billions of habitable planets, and do your next mission? What is your purpose of current living?

An excellent lay-person's ticket into the big show of theoretical, and some basic, physics. He covers everything from the Big Bang to M-Theory, to Schroedinger's cat. No math smarts necessary for this book. He paints a picture of the world of physics that even a regular, non-mathematical person can appreciate. Michio Kaku is a frequent guest on Coast to Coast AM with George Noory. He is always fascinating and entertaining.

This is popular science writing at its best. This book is a gripping journey into the cosmos from the big bang, to quantum theory, and much much more. Yes, the idea of alternative universes might be a speculative one, but Kaku's presentation of the idea is compelling and the journey he takes you on in this book is both highly informative and enjoyable. This is the best science book I have ever read.

Just the intellectual food my brain was craving!“...the laws of physics, carefully constructed after thousands of years of experimentation, are nothing but the laws of harmony one can write down for strings and membranes. The laws of chemistry are the melodies that one can play on these strings. the universe is a symphony of strings. And the "Mind of God," which Einstein wrote eloquently about, is cosmic music resonating throughout hyperspace.”

This book was crazy good, but my lack of deep understanding of physics led to a 3 star rating. As the book pressed on, I got over my head into quantum mechanics & theory. It became like white noise after a continue flushing through of the dynamics of string vs m theory. Basically, I enjoyed it completely until the 1/2 mark when I drown in theories from that point on. It was well narrated. Overall, science people will love this book. I dug it...well, what I could.

Incredible! Fantastic! This is the third book by Kaku I've read and they have all warranted high praise. The book covers incredibly deep theories in an easy to comprehend fashion worthy of the armchair scientist. I would recommend being at least somewhat familiar with basic string theories before diving in (Hawking's "Universe in a Nutshell" would be a good place to start), but overall it's well worth the time it takes to wade through it. It's not really light reading though, so be warned.

inspirational book!..i simply love astrophysics..& this book contributed so much..as michio kaku's other books, this book is also written for general peoples..this book doesn't deal with equations much but i think he(michio kaku) don't expect everybody will understand those complex equations..so he wrote the book as simple as possible but explaining the mutliverse theory at the same time..the point is I got interested in astrophysics..so i should be thankful to michio kaku!..a job well done.

So....if you had to pick a science book...go with Pulp Physics. This is a good one...but infinitely more confusing...and the author is way way way way out there. For all his work and theorizing...his end game...to enter a supposed parallel universe for when ours runs cold...is so crazy...so impossible...so utterly wrought with unlikelihoods...that it reads like science fiction. I've seen this author talk on tv....which is why I took a roll on the book...but wow it is out there.

This guy needs an editor. Lots of digression and straying from the topic, which is not a good idea when you are dealing with theoretical astrophysics. Make this 30% shorter and you have a killer. Ferris is a better writer on this stuff but he doesn't get as wacky and fun as Kaku, who actually tells you (eventually) why sci fi tropes are possible or impossible. Some of it feels like it was written on plane rides between keynote speeches. Again, where is the editor?

FascinatingMichio Kaku is one of my favorite physicists, because he is able to explain complex theories in a way that the layman can understand. Though this book was written some years ago, most of it still applies today in the world of physics. The multiuniverse theory is very possible, even probable, according to string theory and M theory. Understanding this subject is important to the possibilities of our future survival.

Is the universe in which we find ourselves just one of many inter connected universes? Michio Kaku takes us an an incredible journey into the of quantum particles, string theories and what they could mean for us and where we exist. He shows us the worlds of Albert Einstein, Neils Bohr and the scientists that have followed as they work to unravel the mysteries of the universe. It is an entertaining and thought provoking book that I recommend to anyone interested in where the universe came from.

I have a degree in History. This should imply that math is conspicuously absent from my skill sets. I found this book to be an enjoyable and regularly gripping overview of quantum physics, a subject that makes me wish I could do numbers. As of this writing, the book is only a little out-of-date. It is distractingly sad reading the author describe with excitement several projects that NASA has since scrapped.

Great synopsis of present day understanding of the cosmos (and a good deal of the history of our understanding through explanations of the physicists and theoretical physicists who led the discoveries)up to M-Theory. Michio presents a number of "what-if" scenarios that make one think and that allow us to contextualize the importance of contemporary acts on our potential to meet the cosmological challenges facing the earth in the distant future. Highly recommended.

Michio Kaku always does a great job of explaining complicated scientific concepts for schlubs like me. This book is no exception - though at times he does move a little fast for me. But this is a great book for not only understanding scientific concepts like quantum physics, string theory, gravity, and m-verse theory, but also getting the history of how these ideas developed over time and the experiments that led to them.

Really enjoyed this book, love the author. Very skilled at explaining difficult concepts down to an understandable level."The most beautiful experience we can have is the mysterious. It is the fundamental emotion which stands at the cradle of true art and true science. Whosoever does not know it and can no longer wonder, no longer marvel, is as good as dead, and his eyes are dimmed." --Albert Einstein

I have read a few books on the subjects of relativity and quantum physics, but this author puts it together better than the others. Michio Kaku is the non-physicist's best friend when it comes to explaining the nature of everything. I really enjoyed this and have a much better feel for the vastness of the universe, the origin of time, and the concepts of string theory and parallel universes. Spoiler-There are still mysteries to solve!

Wow,..around chapter 7 I think my mind exploded.Ok this is how this book reads, imagine your eatingthe most delicious looking juice meal you have ever had. One bite you savor you chew and chew and slowly swallow oh that's good you say, then your nextthought is oh my I'm full you look at your book you have read just six pages 355 pages to go. Oh my such a thickmental meal enjoyed it but took a good deal of time to read

Accessible, readable account of high level physics with a very science fiction bent: the book is structured around the idea that our species will (if it survives) one day need to escape a dying universe. Dr. Kaku outlines the possible escape routes that are theoretically possible (i.e., do not violate current physics).

I feel like there's a whole set of boilerplate explanations out there for basic issues in contemporary physics. Writers like Kaku just take those 100 or so pages and scatter their handful of newish concepts throughout. That being said, he's got some terrific newish concepts in this book -- supersymmetry, M-theory and branes, and so on -- worth a skim, at least.

Lots of existentialism in here I felt, which didn't really bother me. There's a cold-bleak future for us in the coming billions of years and Kaku provides the potential for finding ways to survival within the bounds of physics. Really liked the part where Kaku provided similarities between our universe and a black hole.

More pop than sci, still worth a read. Kaku sums up the history of physics leading up to M-theory in a rather readable though dumbed down way.Readers looking for a more technical approach covering a lot of areas described here should read Lee Smolin's "The problem with Physics" and Susskind's reply to Smolin - "The cosmic landscape"

This is an excellent layman's survey of the various cosmology theories as well as historical background. A general overview of quantum mechanics, string theory, general relativity is given along with speculations on the evolution of civilization and intelligence and the ultimate fate of the universe and if there are multiple universes.

This book was a really interesting book by Michio Kaku as it proposed ideas based on physics principles and ideas of the universe that seem very interesting, such as the existence of parallel universes. Thus, although I was confused during some sections of the book, it provided a sufficient amount of background information and ideas to enable you to understand the proposed ideas.

This was a great book on Parallel universes, black holes, multiple dimensions, and classes of civilizations. It was more than I could process at times, but the science is so mind-blowing, that getting bored is not an option. If you are looking for a good introduction to M-Theory, Cosmology, and multiple dimensions then I think this is the book for you.

More of a catch-all quantum physics book than a comprehensive book on the multiverse/many worlds/parallel universes theory. Still interesting, albeit somewhat of a misleading title. Here's to hoping Brian Greene's The Hidden Reality paints a more thorough picture. Also, this stuff hurts my brain, but in a good way (I guess).

This one was thick. Not as simple to understand as Hawking, but dumbed down for us non physicists. It was tough to follow in places, but well written and I did get answers to some of the questions on parallel universes that I had. Dr. Kaku is a good writer and probably way too smart for me to fully understand.

Great book. It was published quite a while ago so a little of the info is outdated (i.e. as of the last six months, it now looks like we CAN exceed the speed of light). It's still an excellent read for the lay person, however, because Michio Kaku does a great job distilling complicated physics for the average person to understand.

If you are a closet sci-fi geek or just a have physics envy, read this book. Kaku does a terrific job of describing the workings of the cosmos and all the theories that underpin it in terms any one can understand. He also raises some intriguing thoughts relating science, religion, and faith in a Creator. Guaranteed to make you think.

A great read for anyone interested in the modern day very real probabilities of time and space travel, multiverse theories and alternate universes. A general overview that doesn't make an average person feel inadequate while reading a scientific book, though in some parts it does tend to get a little technical and somewhat boring.
